ol.li: A positive integer exponent tells us how many copies of its base to multiply together.

assemblage.title: Definition of Negative and Zero Exponents

ol.li: A negative exponent denotes a reciprocal, as long as the base is not zero. A negative exponent does not mean that the power is negative.

assemblage.title: Power Function
assemblage.p: A function of the form f(x) = kx^p where k and p are nonzero constants, is called a power functionpower function.

ol.li: The laws of exponents are used to simplify products and quotients of powers, not for sums or differences of powers. We can combine (add or subtract) like terms, but we cannot combine terms with different exponents into a single term.

assemblage.title: To Write a Number in Scientific Notation

ol.li: Locate the decimal point so that there is exactly one nonzero digit to its left.

li.p:
Count the number of places you moved the decimal point: this determines the power of 10.
If the original number is greater than 10, the exponent is positive.
If the original number is less than 1, the exponent is negative.

assemblage.title: nth Roots
assemblage.p: s is called an nth root of b if s^n = b.

assemblage.title: Exponential Notation for Radicals
assemblage.p: For any integer n \ge 2 and for a \ge 0, a^{1/n} = \sqrt[n]{a}

ol.li: It is not possible to write down an exact decimal equivalent for an irrational number, but we can find an approximation to as many decimal places as we like.
To solve an equation involving x^n, we first isolate the power, then raise both sides to the exponent \dfrac{1}{n}.

We can solve an equation where one side is an nth root of x by raising both sides of the equation to the nth power. We must be careful when raising both sides of an equation to an even power, as extraneous solutions may be introduced.
Every positive number has two real-valued roots, one positive and one negative, if the index is even.
A negative number has no real-valued root if the index is even.
Every real number, positive, negative, or zero, has exactly one real-valued root if the index is odd.

A fractional exponent represents a power and a root. The denominator of the exponent is the root, and the numerator of the exponent is the power. We will define fractional powers only when the base is a positive number.
Direct variation has the following scaling property: increasing x by any factor causes y to increase by the same factor.
To solve an equation with a fractional exponent we first isolate the power. Then we raise both sides to the reciprocal of the exponent.

li.p: In general, it is not true that \sqrt[n]{a+b} is equivalent to \sqrt[n]{a}+\sqrt[n]{b}, or that \sqrt[n]{a-b} is equivalent to \sqrt[n]{a}-\sqrt[n]{b}.

ol.li: We simplify radicals by factoring out any perfect powers from the radicand.
We can add or subtract like radicals in the same way that we add or subtract like terms, by adding or subtracting their coefficients.
We can use the fundamental principle of fractions to remove radicals from the denominator. This process is called rationalizing the denominator.
Whenever we raise both sides of an equation to an even power, it is possible to introduce false or extraneous solutions.
